entry.definition: Identifiers used within the MACiE dictionary
entry.description: These include the EC number, PDB code (plus any related PDB entries), enzyme name (along with any other names the enzyme might be commonly known as), and organism the enzyme is found in.

entry.definition: Number assigned to a molecule in the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes.
Unique MACiE ID for each entry
Name of the enzyme
Any other names of the enzyme
entry.description: This can be used when the enzyme has more than one name. for example this might be the systematic name whereas the enzymeName may be the common name, or vice versa.

entry.definition: Enzyme Commission classification number
entry.description: This is the classification system developed by the Enzyme Commission (E.C.) in 1961. It relies upon the overall reaction, substrates and products, as well as the reaction direction to classify the enzyme in a four level system.

entry.definition: Main class of the enzyme in the E.C. classification system
entry.description: This can be any number between one and six and represents the top level classification of the enzyme according to the E.C. E.C. 1 are the oxidoreductases, E.C. 2 are the transferases, E.C. 3 are the hydrolases, E.C. 4 are the lyases, E.C. 5 are the isomerases, and E.C. 6 are the ligases.

entry.definition: The subclass of the enzyme
entry.description: This represents the second level of the E.C. classification, the definition of this number depends on the first level of classification. 99 is used when the category of teh sub-subclass is unknown.

entry.definition: The sub-subclass of the enzyme.
entry.description: This represents the third level of E.C. classification, the definition of this number depends on the first two levels of E.C. classification. 99 is used when the category of teh sub-subclass is unknown.

entry.definition: The serial number of the enzyme in its sub-subclass
entry.description: This represents the final level of classification in the E.C. system, when combined with the previous three numbers it gives a unique number to the enzyme classified. This serial number is semantically meaningless.

entry.definition: PDB code which relates directly to the MACiE entry
entry.description: There is usually only one PDB code, however a mechanism sometimes spans more than one domain, in that case there will be two primary PDB codes.

entry.definition: PDB codes which are related to the primary PDB code
entry.description: A few enzymes in the data set have related PDB codes which might contain a ligand of some sort or may be a mutant of the native enzyme. These PDB entries might be contained in this field.

entry.definition: Organism the enzyme comes from
These are the species which are involved in the reaction
entry.description: This can be either reactant/substrate, product, co-factor, intermediate, etc.

entry.definition: Molecule which is not directly involved in the reaction
entry.description: This may be an amino acid, solvent molecule, or simply a reactant which is present during a step but not involved at that stage of the reaction

entry.definition: A chemical species which is consumed during the course of the observed reaction.
A chemical species which is formed during the course of the observed reaction.

Chemical species with a lifetime appreciably longer than a molecular vibration that is formed from the reactants and reacts further to give the products of a chemical reaction, or another intermediate
A chemical species which is required (but not consumed) by the enzyme in order for the enzyme to be active. This term incorporates both co-factor and co-enzyme.
Those amino acid residues which are involved in an individual reaction step
An atom at which a reaction occurs, such that a bond is either formed, cleaved or altered in order.
Those atoms that are involved in the reaction, i.e. those atoms which undergo some change in their bonding
Those bonds that are involved in the reaction, i.e. those bonds which undergo some change
The general type of bonds involved in the reaction. Only applicable to overall reaction
The general type of atoms involved in the reaction. Only applicable to overall reaction
description of how the products are produced from the substrates
The complete chemical reaction made up of the overall reaction and reaction steps
Overall chemical effect of the reaction steps
An elementary reaction, constituting one of the stages of the overall reaction
This describes the overall effect of the reaction
This describes the basic processes involved in the reaction
This is the step in a reaction which has the slowest rate, thus imposing an upper limit on the overall reaction rate.
A reaction which can proceed in the forward direction as readily as in the reverse direction
entry.description: This can take the value of unknown, yes or no.

entry.definition: A reaction in which the principal product is isomeric with the principal reactant
A reaction in which a racemate is produced from a chiral starting material where one enantiomer is present in excess

Isomerism of the general form GXY=Z = X=YZG where the isomers are readily inter-convertible; the atoms connecting the groups X,Y,Z are typically any of C, H, O or S, and G is a group which becomes an electrofuge (a leaving group which does not carry away the bonding electron pair) or nucleofuge (a leaving group which carries away the electron bonding pair) during isomerisation.
Tautomerisation of the form: H-O-C=C = O=C-C-H
Interconversion of diastereoisomers that have the opposite configuration at only one of two or more tetrahedral stereogenic centres present in the respective molecular entities.
Interconversion between stereoisomeric olefins or cycloalkanes (or hetero-analogues) which differ in the positions of atoms (or groups) relative to a reference plane
Chemical reaction in which concerted reorganization of bonding takes place throughout a cyclic array of continuously bonded atoms.

Molecular rearrangement involving both the creation of a new s-bond between atoms previously not directly linked and the breaking of an existing s-bond. Often accompanied by a concurrent relocation of p-bonds in the molecule, however the total number of p- and s- bonds remains the same
Highly stereoselective thermally allowed [3,3]-sigmatropic rearrangement of allyl vinyl or allyl aryl ethers
entry.description: Usually intramolecular, the mechanism is somewhat similar to that of the Diels-Alder

entry.definition: Base-catalysed condensation of an ester containing an alpha-hydrogen atom with a molecule of the same ester or a different one to give beta-keto esters.
The reversible, base/acid catalysed condensation dimerisation with of carbonyl with an alpha hydrogen. reaction may occur between two aldehydes, two ketones, or an aldehyde and a ketone.
Acid or base catalysed rearrangement of N-glycosides of aldoses to N-glycosides of the corresponding ketoses.
An reaction in which both oxidation and reduction occur.
This is the chemical species which undergoes reduction (gain of electrons)during the course of a redox reaction
This is the chemical species which undergoes oxidation (loss of electrons)during the course of a redox reaction
This is the chemical species which accepts something (electrons or another chemical moiety) during the course of a reaction
A reaction during which nucleophilic attack by water leads to the cleavage of one or more bonds in a reactant
The net loss of one or more electrons, or an increase in an atoms oxidation number or the gain of oxygen and/or loss of hydrogen from an organic substrate.
The net gain of one or more electrons, or a increase in an atoms oxidation number or the loss of oxygen and/or gain of hydrogen from an organic substrate.
The loss of two groups from two different centres with concomitant formation of an unsaturation in the molecule (double or triple bonds) or the formation of a new ring.
The chemical species which is formed during an elimination reaction.
A reaction in which water is one of the products of the reaction
A reaction in which water is eliminated from one of the reacting species.
A reaction in which carbon dioxide is eliminated from one of the reacting species.
A reaction in which an ammonia ia one of the products of the reaction
A reaction in which ammonia is eliminated from one of the reactants.
A reaction during which phosphate (or pyrophosphate) is a product of the reaction
A reaction during which a proton is a product of the reaction
A reaction during which phosphate (or pyrophosphate) is eliminated from one of the reactants
A reaction in which a chemical moiety is transferred from one reacting species to another. The chemical moiety involved in the transfer must be specified.
This is the chemical moiety which is transferred during the group transfer reaction.
This is the chemical species which gains a chemical species or group during a group transfer
A reaction in which two or more reactants (or remote reacting sites within a single reactant) yield a single main product with accompanying formation of water or other small molecule
The formation of a ring compound from a chain by the formation of a new bond.
The formation of a chain compound from a ring by the cleavage of an existing bond.
The joining together of two molecules coupled with the hydrolysis of a pyrophosphate bond in adenosine 5'-triphosphate or a similar triphosphate
The cleavage of a bond by elimination.
A reaction in which a nucleophile attacks an electrophile forming a covalent bond between the reacting species.
A nucleophile is a chemical species that forms a bond to its reaction partner (the electrophile) by donating both bonding electrons.
This is the electrophile in a nucleophilic reaction
A reaction in which an intermediate is formed
The identity of any intermediate formed
A reaction in which the intermediate collapses to either form a product or another intermediate.
The identity of any intermediate collapsed
A reaction in which the initial generation of free radicals occurs.
A reaction in which the free radical causes some chemical change, but is not lost itself.
A reaction in which the free radical is lost by reacting with another free radical.
The formation of an imine bearing a hydrocarbyl group on the nitrogen atom.

The state in which an assembly of atoms, when randomly placed there, would have an equal probability of forming the reactants or of forming the products of the elementary reaction. This is not an isolatable state, unlike an intermediate. When this is used as an amino acid function the amino acid forms part of the transition state
When this is used as an amino acid function the amino acid forms part of the transition state
The substrate(s) bind to the enzyme's active site
The product leaves the active site of the enzyme during this step
The DNA substrate of the reaction uncoils during this reaction step.
The separation of a molecular entity into two or more molecular entities or the separation of the constituents of any aggregate of molecular entities.
The bonds in the substrate rotate such that the product of the rotation is in the correct orientation for the next reaction step
One or more covalent bonds are cleaved, either heterolytically or homolytically, during the associated reaction.
The identity of the bond broken during the course of a reaction
The type of bond broken during the course of a reaction.
The type of bond changed during the course of a reaction.
The type of bond made during the course of a reaction.bo
One or more covalent bonds are created during the associated reaction.
The identity of the bond created during the course of a reaction
A reaction where one or more bonds under go a change of order

entry.term: Bond Changed during Bond Order Change
entry.definition: The identity of the bond which is altered during a bond order change
The starting type of the bond involved in a bond order change.
The initial order of a bond involved in a bond order change.
The final type of the bond involved in a bond order change.
The final order of a bond involved in a bond order change.
The formation of charge over a bond.
The bond within a chemical species which is polarized
This is where charge spreads out over a number of bonds in the chemical species.
The bonds within a chemical species over which charge is delocalized
A product listed in the overallReaction is produced in this reactionStep.
A reactant listed in the overallReaction is used in this reactionStep
The enzyme is returned to its natural state during the course of this reaction

Chemical species contains a nitrogen, oxygen, or sulphur atom with at least one available lone pair. This then forms a weak interaction with an entity containing a nitrogen, oxygen or sulphur atom which is covalently bound to at least one hydrogen atom.
Chemical species which accepts a proton from another chemical species involved in a reaction step.
Chemical species which has an available pair of electrons capable of forming a covalent bond with a proton (Bronsted base) or with the vacant orbital of some other species (Lewis base).
Chemical species which has an available pair of electrons capable of forming a covalent bond with a proton
Chemical species which has an available pair of electrons capable of forming a covalent bond with the vacant orbital of some other species
Chemical species which is capable of donating a proton (Bronsted acid) or capable of forming a covalent bond with an electron pair (Lewis acid).
Chemical species which is capable of forming a covalent bond with an electron pair
Chemical species which is capable of donating a proton
An electrophile is a chemical species that forms a bond to its reaction partner (the nucleophile) by accepting both bonding electrons.
Chemical species which accepts a free radical during the course of the reaction
Chemical species which stabilises a free radical carrying species during the course of the reaction
The cleavage of a bond so that each of the molecular fragments between which the bond is broken retains one of the bonding electrons.
The cleavage of a covalent bond so that both bonding electrons remain with one of the two fragments between which the bond is broken,
A reaction, either elementary or stepwise, in which one atom or group in a molecular entity is replaced by another atom or group.

A chemical reaction of two or more reacting molecular entities, resulting in a single reaction product containing all atoms of all components, with formation of two chemical bonds and a net reduction in bond multiplicity in at least one of the reactants.
In an elimination two groups are lost most often from two different centres with concomitant formation of an unsaturation in the molecule (double bond, triple bond) or formation of a new ring.
A nucleophilic substitution reaction is a heterolytic reaction in which the reagent supplying the entering group acts as a nucleophile.
The nucleophilic substitution reaction proceeds with first order, i.e. the rate determining step of the reaction involves only one chemical species
The nucleophilic substitution proceeds with second order kinetics i.e. the rate determining step of the reaction involves the collision of two chemical species.

Nucleophilic substitution at an aromatic system. Two essential steps are involved in this, attack of a nucleophilic reagent upon the aromatic system to form a carbanion and the expulsion of a negatively charged group from this carbanion to yield the product
Nucleophilic substitution in which both the nucleophile and electrophile are in the same molecule.
An electrophilic substitution reaction is a heterolytic reaction in which the reagent supplying the entering group acts as an electrophile.
The electrophilic substitution reaction proceeds with first order, i.e. the rate determining step of the reaction involves only one chemical species
The electrophilic substitution proceeds with second order kinetics i.e. the rate determining step of the reaction involves the collision of two chemical species.

Electrophilic substitution at an aromatic system. Two essential steps are involved in this, attack by an electrophilic reagent upon the aromatic ring to form a carbocation and abstraction of a proton by this carbocation by some base.
A substitution reaction which proceeds via a free radical mechanism
The homolytic substitution reaction proceeds with first order, i.e. the rate determining step of the reaction involves only one chemical species
The homolytic substitution proceeds with second order kinetics i.e. the rate determining step of the reaction involves the collision of two chemical species.
An elimination reaction which proceeds via first order kinetics. The rate determining step involves only one chemical species undergoing a covalency change
An elimination reaction which proceeds via second order kinetics. The rate determining step involves two chemical species undergoing covalency changes.
An elimination reaction in which all the components are in the same chemical species.
The addition of a chemical species over a double bond where the double bond is the attacking moiety
The internal addition accross a double bond where the double bond is the attacking moiety
The addition of one chemical species to another via a homolytic mechanism
The addition of one chemical species to another via a nucleophilic mechanism
Location of residue function
An amino acid residue performing its catalytic function via its side chain moiety (or R group)
An amino acid residue performing a catalytic function via either the main chain amide or carboxyl moiety
The main chain amide section of an amino acid
The main chain carboxyl section of an amino acid
An atom or group (charged or uncharged) that becomes detached from an atom in what is considered to be the residual or main part of the substrate.
The function of the amino acid residue
An amino acid which is necessary in order that catalysis may occur, but is not necessarily actively involved in the reaction
entry.description: An example of an onlooker is a residue which will stabilise the negative charge on an oxyanion, and is not involved in the formation of the oxyanion.

entry.definition: An amino acid residue whose function is to stabilise positive or negative charge that has built during the course of a reaction step.
An amino acid residue whose function is to destabilise positive or negative charge that has built during the course of a reaction step.
The amino acid residue is covalently attached to another chemical species.
The amino acid residue hinders access to the reacting chemical species by virtue of its bulk
The amino acid residue perterbates the reactive species in a purely steric manner to induce reaction.
entry.description: This is used when the steric role played by the amino acid is unclear.

entry.definition: The amino acid residue is involved in a proton relay, i.e. it acts as both base and acid during the course of the reaction
The amino acid residue is involved in a hydride relay, i.e. it both accepts and donates a H- during the course of the reaction.
A chemical species which donates something (electrons or some other chemical moiety) to a reaction during the course of a the reaction
This is the chemical species which donates electrons during the course of a reaction
This is the chemical species which accepts electrons during the course of a reaction
This is the chemical species which donates one electron during the course of a reaction
This is the chemical species which donates two electrons during the course of a reaction
This is the chemical species which loses the group transferred
Chemical species which donates a proton to another residue, substrate, cofactor or other moiety involved in a reaction step.

Chemical species contains a nitrogen, oxygen or sulphur atom which is covalently bound to at least one hydrogen atom. This then forms a weak interaction with an entity which contains a nitrogen, oxygen, sulphur or halogen with at least one available lone pair
Chemical species which starts off with a free radical and loses it during the course of the reaction
A chemical species which is activated in some way during the course of the reaction
The activation of a chemical species by light.
The overall product and reactant list of the reaction
The metadata relating to the overall reaction scheme.
Annotation relating to the overall reaction.
Literature reference.
List of the literature references used.
Metadata associated with an individual reaction stage.
Annotation associated with an individual reaction stage.
The amino acid is bound to a metal ion as a ligand of that ion.
The amino acid is binds the substrate molecule.
The amino acid's function is not know for this reaction, although it is suspected that it may play an active part.
